action.action-desc: Mr. Paulsen (for himself, Mr. Quigley, and Mr. Renacci) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend the Immigration and Nationality Act to authorize certain aliens who have earned a Ph.D. degree from a United States institution of higher education in a field of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics to be admitted for permanent residence and to be exempted from the numerical limitations on H–1B nonimmigrants.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Stopping Trained in America Ph.D.s From Leaving the Economy Act of 2015 or the STAPLE Act.

section.header: Exemption from numerical limitations on permanent residents for certain United States educated immigrants

subsection.header: Aliens not subject to direct numerical limitations
subsection.text: Section 201(b)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1151(b)(1)) is amended by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: Aliens who have earned a Ph.D. degree from a United States institution of higher education (as defined in section 101(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001(a))) in a field of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics and who have an offer of employment from a United States employer in a field related to such degree.

subsection.text: Section 204(a)(1)(F) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1154(a)(1)(F)) is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking Attorney General and inserting Secretary of Homeland Security.

section.header: Exemption from H–1B numerical limitation for certain United States educated nonimmigrants
section.text: Section 214(g)(5) of the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. 1184(g)(5)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (B), by striking or at the end;
in subparagraph (C), by striking the period at the end and inserting a semicolon; and
by adding at the end the following:

subparagraph.text: has earned a Ph.D. degree from a United States institution of higher education (as defined in section 101(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001(a))) in a field of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics and with respect to whom the petitioning employer requires such education as a condition for the employment.
